We received complaints from the Department of Defense, because we were 
consuming 1MB/second in a sustained way over a 12 hour period.  The 
reason was that (a) they had extremely large documents, sometimes many 
hundreds of megabytes, and (b) we have a pretty good-sized pipe out of 
here.  So we had to impose a domain-based bandwidth limit, and I am also 
in the process of preparing to submit code changes to Heritrix that 
limits the burst download rate for single documents.

It seems the current default setup is tuned well for situations where 
documents are small, but is in fact inadequate for domains where large 
documents reside.

Thanks,
Karl


Kristinn Sigurdsson wrote:
> I've managed several crawls over the .is TLD.  In my experience the default 
> politeness rules
> delay-factor: 5.0
> max-delay-ms: 5000
> min-delay-ms: 500
> have proved more then adequate except in one isolated case where (since we 
> use host based politeness) one domain with many virtual sub-domains (blogs 
> actually) got swamped. But that is really a seperate issue (and might not
> affect
> IP based politeness. The solution in that instance was to force queue 
> assignments to merge all sub-domains with the politness queue of the main
> domain.
>  
> In fact I have run more aggressive crawls without complaints. Most of the 
> complaints I do get are because of Heritrix's aggressive link extractions
> that
> leads to 404 content (often soft 404) that's showing up in server logs.
>  
> I've never imposed a per-server bandwidth limitation. The only reason why 
> you might want to do that (that I can think off relating to crawl
> politeness) 
> is if you are crawling personal domains where people have limited bandwidth 
> (in that once exceeded the service provider blocks access). Otherwise, 
> adjusing the politness factors seems more appropriate. (That's just my
> opinion 
> of course, there may also be reasons relating to crawling strategies 
> - balancing - for doing this, but that is another subject).
>  
> I would be very interested in hearing exactly what the complaints you have 
> recieved where? 
>  
> Also, I know that our activities (National Library doing legal deposit)
> have met with a lot of goodwill so I'm sure that many site admins that might
> complain to some random harvester, are tolerating us.
>  
> - Kris
>
